WRITING.TEXT: I'm so excited, to be honest. I'm the kind of fan, in all sports, that wants my favorite team/fighter to lose to the best. If Stipe beats Werdum, well, that just means Arlovski lost to the champ, right? ;).

Just read this book last year around this time. I LOVED it so much more than I expected. But there is one chapter in that book, somewhere in the teens, I don't remember which, that was the most tedious thing I've ever read in my life. All of the video game and fish descriptions we've previously experienced got nothing on this.
*Checked my Goodreads review* It's Chapter 11. Quoted from my review: I was *this* close to giving the book a three, based on chapter 11 alone, but as the story progressed and the finale approached, I forgot all about how tedious (though significant) that particular section of the book was, and just fell back in love with Wilde's prose.

A few weeks ago I was doing some stuff at work that required my computer to run without me interfering with it, so I spent some time on a site that pointed out all of the differences between the film and the book. I had just seen the film the night before, and was really pleased to see that while there were a number of differences, for the most part, it was a great adaptation, that didn't leave TOO much out.

I hated that about the movie, to be honest. They didn't work Bell in nearly as well as I thought they did in the book, so when he has this monologue at the end of the film, it just feels like the whole film was a set up for that one monologue. In the book, you always realize you're reading Bell's story,and he punctuates it with this one event that really changed the way he looked at everything.
I think the point of the book as a whole was that while the protagonist continued to claim that the world was going to hell, there kept being evidence that the world has always had evil in it.

But, I do like that they seem to be their own story as well, and I find them fascinating. The lengths which he has gone to make this fictional world are really something else. I can't think of another book I've seen like this.

Probably definitely, I think.
But that wasn't what the author wanted to happen, and it's dark and it's always sat weird with me, lol.
That's insane, I love it!

I really wish Magomedov would get a better fight. I realize he's "boring", but low-key (and IMO of course), he's super talented at what he does. Maybe the striking power will come in time, I don't know, but I think the fight IQ makes up for it, and I'd REALLY like to see him fight a ranked opponent. Not sure why he almost seems to have been downgraded after picking Jordan apart the way he did.

I was mildly infuriated by this at first, until their logic was explained for doing it: People are more likely to follow the doctor's recommendation for how often to change their contacts if they have more pairs of them to spare.
Now, that doesn't excuse the poor packaging, but, maybe the reasoning will help a little.

Started really getting serious about a lifestyle change last January, after a few years of yo-yoing. At my worst, a few years back, I was at 190. I started 2015 at 170. Got down to 135. I am 5'1.5", so I'm now "overweight" rather than obese. I hit that weight in July. I didn't lose another pound the rest of the year. It was maddening. Then the holidays hit and I didn't go to the gym for two months. Got terrified that I'd gained back too much weight to cope with.
Anyways, my point is, I started reading here, and it really got me motivated. I've been back on my regular gym schedule for a few days in a row, now, and I'm super hyped to be there again. Turned out I only gained back about 6 or 7 pounds in the holiday months (one of my problems is that I seem to gain weight back REALLY quickly if I don't stick to my calorie goals). I'm already back down two pounds from my new peak, so I'm really happy to be back on the train.
Here's to hoping I can get down to my target weight before my 10 year high school reunion in August ;).
Thank you all so much for the motivation!
One thing that was nice about getting married was having someone to share poptarts with so I could still eat them, but not feel TOO bad about it _

I'm not looking forward to the harsh reality coming my way when I get a fitbit in a few days and it starts tracking my exercise calories more accurately ;_;.
But, in general, I try not to eat back my exercise calories, anyways, unless it was one of my double days at the gym, because...doesn't that kind of defeat the purpose? MFP actually had a decent article about this on the app a few months back, about whether or not you should eat back the calories.

See, this is the kind of thing where I think the logic of not focusing too strongly on the numbers is important.
I'm not saying the numbers are wrong, but if you're feeling better, and you're losing weight, take that as a positive in the right direction, and don't overwhelm yourself with the target. If you keep doing what you're doing, and focus on that, the rest would hopefully come in time.
I'm 5'1", am 20 pounds overweight and wear between a size 8 and size 10 US. So, yeah, the second I read she was a size 10, I was like, "OK, so she's a little overweight, actually."
Thank...you...

I read another book from the top 10. I'll be doing that for half of the books next month.

Funny because true.
It's amusing that I could find myself so actively disliking the reading experience of a book, but still coming away from it feeling like I really enjoyed it. What a strange little story.
I'll never forgive how short the chapter with the poulps was, though. That was the one thing I remembered from the movie way back when, and I was looking forward to it, and it was over so suddenly.

Having already seen the film (and been one of the few people to not love it), I was very anxious upon realizing how close an adaptation of the book the film is.
A good chunk of the way in, now, my fears are assuaged. This book is wonderful. It's also making me believe that if I were to watch the film again, I'd change my mind about it as well.
I've been forced to split my time between an audio book version, and reading it myself, as I got very behind slogging through 20KLUTS. This has proved to be a bit tedious, as the audiobook version is a little hard to follow, due to the strange way this book is written. But, that being said, that coinflip scene is EVEN BETTER than in the film, and the film scene is already incredible.
Yes, I am enjoying this quite a bit, indeed.

I finally finished this.
I really wanted to like it. I liked it a great deal in the beginning. In the end, I just... well, I enjoyed the story, but it was one of the most tedious reading experiences of my life.
Still, it is what it is, there's a wonderful narrative here, and for its time, wow. So, 7/10 bordering on a 6.

Still Alice.
In general just the thought of Alzheimers depresses me, but with it being a story about early onset, I just completely lost it watching the movie.
About halfway through I was nearly sobbing aloud. My husband kept asking if I wanted to turn the movie off, but I couldn't stand not knowing what happens, so I spent the next 40 minutes having various crying fits until the nightmare was finally over.
It was not my favorite movie watching experience. Great movie though.

My step-father's dad used to do this before he passed away. He and his wife would take a stroll down to the golf course and fish out lost golf balls and then he'd sell them in a little stand in his front yard to people on their way to the course.
He had a really great collection of the more unique ones he found in his house as well.
But certainly by no means did he make THAT kind of money.

When I went on a high school trip to Japan, one of my friends took a bunch of the biscuits and put them in her bag and walked around with several deer following her, singing songs from Snow White. It was hilarious at the time, but knowing what I know now, in hindsight, I'm really glad those deer didn't just straight murder her.

Hah, sorry, it's true, I really did NOT like the book at all. That being said, I realize a good portion of a chapter was dedicated to him getting in shape. That wasn't my point. My point was that while other characters had some physical flaws, by the time anyone ever saw Wade in person, he was fit as a fiddle.
My mistake, thank you. I must have missed that. It's still glossed over, but, yeah, at least it wasn't just tossed in arbitrarily at the end like I perceived it to have been.

I grew up in the 90s (born 1987), and I still got nearly every reference. I was kinda surprised to hear how "obscure" they were, but I'm certainly not trying to come off as, "I know more about pop culture than you." by any means. I admit, though, I'm pretty obsessed with the 80s...

That indentured servitude thing at the end was a great subplot. I hated that he threw it in at the end, just like the reveal about Aech, seemingly as though he thought about it, AS he was writing, and figured, "well, I'll just add it to the story now, we don't need any kind of clues that this is happening in the real world, to maybe clue the reader in to the larger universe this is all happening in."
YES, it was SO perfect, I was also expecting nearly this exact twist.

Wade was chubby until he wasn't, remember. Right before he met Art3mis in person, he had just enough time to slim down and build some muscle. He was chubby for a minute, but by the end, like everything else about his character, he was right back to nearly perfect.

I've said a lot of negative things about this book already, so I'll save it for now, I just have one big thing I want to get across:
Saying this is good for a YA novel is NOT a good enough excuse.
You want to know what's a great YA novel rooted in sci-fi, similar in theme to this one? Ender's Game.
You DON'T have to sacrifice substance to be geared at younger readers. Ender's is a *fantastic* book. As an adult, I was blown away by it. There was nothing about it that felt like it was lacking, in order to be a youth-aimed story.
This book felt like it used the YA tag as an excuse to avoid substance. There's no excuse for that.
In short, as I've said so many times before: This book could have been good. It wasn't. But Spielberg will very likely make something incredible out of it. So there's that.

I audibly groaned in an overly dramatic way at one REALLY bad line in the book as a joke, (I think it was near the end after Aech's big reveal), but my husband thought I had literally become sick to my stomach and was about to throw up. That was worth a few laughs.

He talks about being able to just pick up a computer, from an early age, and program it. The only time he talks about learning in his early years are with those children's games...I can't imagine he learned programming from that.
It just bothers me when an author says something like, "I found a laptop and reprogrammed it to do x." or "I hacked it to let me listen to music."
It's just kinda lazy. It is what it is. It's not like THAT was the one thing that turned me off the book.
Ha, I said something along these lines to a coworker a few weeks ago as a joke. Had no idea it was a current conspiracy theory.

But how does he learn these abilities? Even if you're a prodigy, you have to have some sort of understanding of how programming works.
One sentence saying, he's just good at it, ok? Isn't enough for me.
I think it'll make a great movie, fwiw. Don't think they could've picked a better director.
My husband asked me if I disliked the book because it was too long. I told him no, it's too short. He needed to do a lot more character and world building.

I mentioned this in another conversation, but I had completely expected [Shoto and Daito](/s "to turn out to just be American's who were REALLY into Japanese culture. That's how they were written.")
I've studied Japanese for the better part of my life now. Interact with many Japanese people, have been to Japan, etc...this depiction was so cringe-inducing, I could hardly continue reading once their characters were introduced.
It's one thing to have them say ~san. But that seppuku line drop was potentially the worst sentence I've ever read in any book ever.

I don't mean to come into this thread and just post a bunch of negative stuff, but I've been holding a lot of it in, and I felt like this was a good thread to just vent a lot of frustrations in.
I can't stand books/movies/whatever, that introduce a character as complete computer geniuses, without any means whatsoever for them to become such.
Wade quickly tells us at the beginning of the story that he's just able to do these things, even though he's from a poor background, and would have had no means with which to learn any of it. There's no explanation, no throwaway dialogue where he says something like, "I spent all of my time online learning to code." Nothing. He's just great at it, cause Wade is awesome, and we all need to just accept that.

Gotta make sure the author can have one more chance to let us all know how enlightened he is by having a quickly introduced [characteristic setup](/s "that allows him to deliver the line, "I didn't care about her race, creed or sexuality"). It was so lame, because Aech's character was one of the few I REALLY liked, and deserved more time to grow.

Ugh, yes. He's such a (what's the male word? Matt Sue?) of what the author seems to wish he was like, or something. I just couldn't stand anything he had to say or do for the most part. Like, seriously, there are billions of dollars at stake [and you're](/s "more concerned about some infatuation with a person you've never met? It can wait...")
YES. At the very least, I expected it to turn out that they weren't actually Japanese. That would've been forgivable.

The Japanese hurt my soul...a lot. That was terrible, TERRIBLE writing.
As for the "worldbuilding", there wasn't much of that at all since Cline just took a bunch of stuff that already existed and just threw it at the wall to see what stuck.
I was really disappointed in the book, but I think it'll make a killer movie in Spielberg's hands.
People acting like Lawler got destroyed in that fight or something...
Hah.

But if you look at his fight record since the four fight losing streak, I don't know how you aren't impressed with it. In 12 fights, he had one loss and one NC. The NC would've been a win, and the one loss was slightly controversial, in that he got ROCKED by a hit that was possibly long after the bell. Even then, just the one loss to Johnson in four and a half years, as a heavyweight, is impressive.
I miss him dearly, and even if he wasn't "our" guy, all of the celebration of his career the last few weeks has made me so proud.

I still think he has some great fights in him. I think the Rothwell rematch is an inevitability, for example, and there's some other fun matchups with some of the greats he hasn't fought, like Barnett, JDS and Hunt. And hell, maybe if he wins a few in a row again, we have a different conversation. I did forget he was all the way up to #2 in the rankings.
Can confirm.
This was how I felt after the MSU / TCU game. TCU's my alma mater, but I'd been a fan of MSU (albeit a backseat one) since I was a little kid. When TCU lost I was like..."OK...That's...OK?"
I just can't see it being Condit's round.
